course.subject: MATH
course.name: Introduction to Scattering and Inverse Scattering Theory
course.description: Waves are ubiquitous. They propagate in various media and interact with inhomogeneities therein. The study of how the presence of inhomogeneity affects the propagation of waves is called scattering theory, while the study of how to infer useful information about the inhomogeneities  from the perturbed waves is call inverse scattering theory. The latter lies in the heart of many applications such as bio-medical imaging, nondestructive testing and geophysics et al. In this course, we aim to provide an introduction to both scattering and inverse scattering theory with emphasise on the latter. We will start with 1D scalar case and move to the multi-dimensional cases gradually. We shall focus on the important ideas and attempt to avoid technicalities. Students without course prerequisite should seek instructor's approval to take the course.
course.prerequisites: (MATH 1014 OR MATH 1018 OR MATH 1020 OR MATH1024) AND (MATH 2350 OR MATH 2351 OR MATH 2352)
